column1: 7. The effect of poly phase currents in poly phase winding can be compared to _______________
column2: a) Mechanical rotation of permanent magnets at synchronous speed
column3: b) Mechanical rotation of DC excited field poles at synchronous speed
column4: c) Mechanical rotation of either permanent magnets or DC excited field poles, at synchronous speed
column7: Explanation: The speed at which rotating magnetic field revolves is called the synchronous speed and this effect is equivalent to mechanical rotation of permanent magnets or DC excited field poles.

column1: 8. The magnitude of rotating flux _____________ at all instants of time.
column7: Explanation: FR = 3/(2Fm) (for a 3 phase machine). A constant amplitude rotating MMF or rotating field is produced in the air gap of a three phase machine.

column1: 9. The amplitude of rotating MMF wave is proportional to
column7: Explanation: FR = 3/(2Fm) = 3/(2 4√2/(_Kw NphI/P)where  Nph = series turns per phase and I = RMS current.

column1: 10. If F1 is the constant amplitude of fundamental rotating MMF wave, the space harmonics of order 6K+1 (where K=1,2,3….), the harmonic MMF wave is of _____________
column2: a) Constant amplitude and stationary in space
column3: b) Constant amplitude and rotates along F1
column4: c) Varying amplitude and rotates along F1
column5: d) Constant amplitude and rotates against F1
column7: Explanation: Space harmonics of the order of 6K+1(7,13,19,…) have their constant amplitude equal to 1/(6K+1)F1 and rotate in the direction of fundamental component F1 at a speed of 1/(6K+1) of the fundamental synchronous speed.

column1: 1. If F1 is the constant amplitude of fundamental rotating MMF wave, the for the space harmonics of order 6K-1 (where K=1,2,3….), the harmonic MMF wave is of _____________
column2: a) Constant amplitude and stationary in space
column3: b) Constant amplitude and rotates along F1
column4: c) Varying amplitude and rotates along F1
column5: d) Constant amplitude and rotates against F1
column7: Explanation: Space harmonics of the order of 6K-1(5,11,17,…) have their constant amplitude equal to 1/(6K-1)F1 and rotate in the direction of fundamental component F1 at a speed of 1/(6K+1) of the fundamental synchronous speed.

column1: 2. Which of the following harmonics are present in the resultant MMF produced by 3 phase currents flowing in the 3 phase windings?
column2: a) Triplen harmonics (3K), where K is an integer
column3: b) 6K+1 harmonics only, where K is an integer
column4: c) 6K-1 harmonics only, where K is an integer
column5: d) 6k+1 and 6K-1 harmonics, where K is an integer
column7: Explanation: Space harmonics of the order 3,9,15,… i.e, triplen harmonics are absent.

column1: 3. When a single-phase winding is excited by an alternating current, then which of the following statements are correct?
column2: a) It produces one stationary MMF wave
column3: b) Produced MMF wave pulsates along its magnetic axis
column4: c) It doesn’t produce two counter rotating MMF wave
column7: Explanation: It is the decomposition of the MMF of a single phase winding into two counter rotating MMF waves, but are not actually produced and only one stationary MMF wave pulsating along its magnetic axis is produced.

column1: 4. What does the space angle _ in the equation Fr(_,t)=3/2Fmcos(_-_t) for MMF produced when 3-phase balanced windings excited by three phase balanced currents represent?
column2: a) MMF wave at any moment is sinusoidally distributed in space
column3: b) Entire MMF waveform is travelling at (constant angular speed) synchronous speed
column4: c) MMF wave is of constant amplitude
column7: Explanation: The space angle _ means that MMF wave at any moment is sinusoidally distributed in space along the air-gap periphery.

column1: 5. Three phase voltages are applied to the three windings of an electrical machine. If any two supply terminals are interchanged, then the rotating MMF wave _____________
column4: c) Direction remains same, amplitude alters
column5: d) Direction remains same, amplitude unaltered
column7: Explanation: The direction of rotating MMF wave is reversed, though its amplitude remains unaltered.

column1: 6. The rotating MMF wave of constant amplitude can be produced, only if the time angle displacement between currents is _____________
column2: a) Less than the space angle displacement between winding axis
column3: b) More than the space angle displacement between winding axis
column4: c) Equal to the space angle displacement between winding axis
column7: Explanation: If the time angle displacement between currents and space angle displacement between winding axis are not equal, the magnitude of resultant MMF wave is always zero.

column1: 7. A 3 phase star connected winding is fed from symmetrical 3 phase supply with their neutrals connected together. If one of the 3 supply lines gets disconnected, then the revolving MMF wave will have a ___________
column2: a) Constant amplitude but sub synchronous speed
column3: b) Varying amplitude but synchronous speed
column4: c) Constant amplitude but super synchronous speed
column5: d) Varying speed and a speed fluctuating around the synchronous speed
column7: Explanation: With one supply phase disconnected, a rotating MMF wave of varying amplitude is produced, but at a speed fluctuating around the synchronous speed.

column1: 8. In case of the 3 phase winding with delta or star connection without neutral, if one of the supply lines gets disconnected, then the MMF becomes __________
column4: c) Rotating with sub synchronous speed
column5: d) Rotating with super synchronous speed
column7: Explanation: Disconnection of one of the supply leads, results in single-phase operation of the machine.

column1: 9. If _m is the maximum value of flux due to any one phase, then resultant flux in 2 phase and 3 phase AC machines would respectively be given by _________
column7: Explanation: In a 2 phase and 3 phase AC machine, rotating MMF is produced with magnitudes of _m and 3/2_m.

column1: 1. Which of the following two windings produces/induces the working flux and working EMF respectively?
column2: a) field winding and armature winding
column3: b) armature winding and field winding
column4: c) both are produced in field winding
column5: d) both are produced in armature winding
column7: Explanation: Field winding produces the working flux and armature winding has the working EMF, which is induced by the working flux.

column1: 2. Armature winding carries which of the following current?
column4: c) both magnetizing current and load current
column7: Explanation: The winding on the machine that carries only load current is called armature winding.

column1: 3. Field winding carries which of the following current?
column4: c) both exciting current and load current
column7: Explanation: The winding that handles only exciting current is called field winding.

column1: 4. Which of the following statements are correct regarding exciting current?
column2: (i) exciting current varies with the load
column3: (ii) exciting current doesn’t vary with load
column4: (iii) exciting current produces only a working magnetic flux
column5: (iv) exciting current is not responsible for the production of working  magnetic flux
column7: Explanation: The current that produces only a working magnetic flux, and does not vary with the load on the machine is called exciting current, magnetizing current or field current.

column1: 5. Current in the field winding is ___________
column7: Explanation: Field winding is always given DC supply and hence current is also DC.

column1: 6. The rating of the armature winding is ___________
column2: a) 1/2 to 2% of the rated power of the machine
column3: b) less than the power rating of the machine
column4: c) greater than the power rating of the machine
column5: d) equal to the power rating of the machine
column7: Explanation: The armature winding handles all the power that is being converted or transformed.

column1: 7. The power rating of the field winding is ___________
column2: a) equal to the power rating of the machine
column3: b) 1/2 to 2% of the rated power of the machine
column4: c) greater than the power rating of the machine
column5: d) less than the power rating of the machine
column7: Explanation: The power input to the DC field winding is dissipated as i2R loss in the field winding (once the required field current is established).

column1: 8. What is the reason behind armature structure for both DC and AC machines being laminated?
column4: c) reduce the eddy current losses
column5: d) for better operating power factor
column7: Explanation: The armature windings of both the DC and AC machines have to deal with alternating current only; this is the reason why the armature structure of all rotating machines are laminated in order to reduce the eddy current losses.

column1: 9. Armature winding is one in which working ___________
column2: a) flux is produced by field current
column3: b) flux is produced by the working emf
column4: c) emf is produced by the working flux
column5: d) emf is produced by the leakage flux
column7: Explanation: In an electrical machine, armature winding is one in which the working emf is induced by the working flux.

column1: 10. Why is the air gap between stator and rotor should be kept as small as mechanically possible in induction motor?
column2: a) to reduce the leakage flux between stator and rotor
column3: b) as it leads to better operating power factor of the induction motor
column4: c) reduce the eddy current losses
column5: d) both, to reduce leakage flux between stator and rotor, and also for better operating power factor
column7: Explanation: The leakage flux and power factor depends on the air gap and it should be as small as possible.

column1: 1. Which type of slots are used in the construction of large size and small size induction motors respectively?
column2: a) open slots and semiclosed slots
column3: b) semiclosed slots and open slots
column4: c) open slots and open slots
column5: d) semiclosed slots and semiclosed slots
column7: Explanation: Large size motors use open slots, so that already prepared and properly insulated coils can be inserted in open slots. Small size induction motors use semiclosed slots, so as to reduce the effective gap length between stator and rotor.

column1: 2. In which of the following applications, wound rotor type of induction motor is used?
column2: a) where the driven load requires speed control
column3: b) where high starting torque is required
column4: c) when external resistance is to be inserted
column7: Explanation: Only in wound rotor type of induction motor, external resistance can be inserted in series with the rotor winding, for speed and starting torque control.

column1: 3. For an induction motor,
column2: (i) squirrel cage type is simpler and more economical in construction
column3: (ii) wound rotor type requires less maintenance
column4: (iii) squirrel cage type is more rugged and requires less maintenance
column5: (iv) no external resistance can be inserted in the rotor circuit of squirrel cage induction motor
column7: Explanation: The squirrel cage type is simpler and more economical in construction, requires less maintenance than wound rotor type, since the former doesn’t require slip rings and carbon brushes.

column1: 4. What are the advantages of providing the field winding on rotor and armature winding on the stator?
column7: Explanation: If the armature winding is on the stator, only two slip rings are required which implies less losses, more efficiency and more economy. Also, stationary armature winding can be cooled more efficiently.

column1: 5. The stator frame and end covers in synchronous and induction machines are designed to ___________
column3: b) to serve as a mechanical support
column4: c) to provide cooling or to carry induced EMF
column7: Explanation: The stator frame and end covers serve merely as a mechanical support to the stator core, and are not designed to carry the magnetic flux.

column1: 6. What is the advantage of connecting two coils in parallel?
column2: a) reduce the amount of copper required
column3: b) increase the current per parallel path to double the value
column7: Explanation: The parallel connection of two coils will increase the current per parallel path to double the value.

column1: 7. In a synchronous machine, salient pole construction has been found to suit best for ___________
column7: Explanation: For accommodating large number of poles, the rotor diameter must be comparatively increased, and from mechanical considerations, salient pole construction has been found to suit best for low speed prime movers.

column1: 8. What is the equation for frequency of generated EMF?
column7: Explanation: f= PN/120 Hz in India and many other countries, alternators feeding the power system generates at a frequency of 50 Hz.

column1: 9. How many poles should the alternators driven by the oil engines and hydraulic turbine prime movers must have, for better operation?
column7: Explanation: Oil engines and hydraulic turbines operate best at relatively low speeds, therefore, the alternators driven by these prime movers must have relatively large number of poles, as f _ 1/N.

column1: 10. Large synchronous machines are constructed with armature winding on the stator because stationary armature winding
column2: (i) can be insulated satisfactorily for higher voltages
column4: (iii) would lead to reduced slip ring losses
column7: Explanation: If the armature winding is on the stator, only two slip rings are required, which implies less losses, more efficiency and more economy. Also, stationary armature windings can be cooled more efficiently.

column1: 1. How many poles should the alternators, driven by the steam and gas turbines prime movers must have, for better operation?
column7: Explanation: Steam and gas turbines have best operating characteristics at relatively high speeds, therefore, alternators driven by these must have a fewer number of poles, say 2 or 4, as f _ 1/N.

column1: 2. In a synchronous machine, cylindrical pole construction has been found to suit best for ___________
column7: Explanation: For high speed prime movers, if salient pole construction is used, the rotor structure may not be able to withstand the enormous centrifugal forces, developed by the salient poles. Therefore, cylindrical rotor construction is best suited from mechanical considerations.

column1: 3. Commercially, which of the following generators is called turbo-alternators or turbo-generators?
column2: a) salient pole rotor synchronous generators
column3: b) cylindrical pole rotor induction generators
column4: c) salient pole rotor induction generators
column7: Explanation: Cylindrical rotor synchronous generators are used commercially at high speed, driven by steam and gas turbines.

column1: 4. For relatively large sizes of synchronous machines, which of the following are used for providing closed circuit cooling?
column7: Explanation: For synchronous machines of large sizes, adequate cooling arrangements must be incorporated to dissipate the heat produced by various losses.

column1: 5. In a synchronous generator, the frequency of the generated EMF depends on
column4: c) both rotational speed and poles
column7: Explanation: f = PN/120 Hz

column1: 6. A synchronous machine can be connected to an energy system only when ___________
column7: Explanation: For successful operation, the rotational speed/frequency of the synchronous machine must synchronize with the frequency of the energy system, and this is the reason for calling it a synchronous machine.

column1: 7. In larger DC machines, the reason behind using fabricated steel instead of cast iron in the manufacture of yoke is ?
column7: Explanation: Fabricated steel has higher permeability than cast iron.

column1: 8. In a DC machine, the pole core is usually of smaller cross section than the pole shoe because ___________
column2: (i) smaller cross section requires less copper
column3: (ii) larger pole shoe increases the air gap reluctance
column4: (iii) larger pole shoe increases the flux per pole entering the armature
column5: (iv) larger pole shoe reduces the mechanical strength
column7: Explanation: Larger pole shoe area increases the flux per pole entering the armature, due to the reduction in air gap reluctance, and it also provides mechanical strength.

column1: 9. In a DC generator, the commutator serves as a _________
column2: a) mechanical rectifier for alternating EMF to direct EMF
column3: b) mechanical inverter to invert the direct applied voltage to alternating voltage
column7: Explanation: A DC generator is equivalent to an AC machine plus a mechanical rectifier, i.e, commutator.

column1: 10. In a DC motor, the commutator serves as a  ___________
column2: a) mechanical rectifier for alternating EMF to direct EMF
column3: b) mechanical inverter to invert the direct applied voltage to alternating voltage
column7: Explanation: A DC motor is equivalent to an AC machine plus a mechanical inverter, i.e, commutator.

column1: 1. Which of the following statements is/are correct regarding the generation of EMF in rotating electrical machines in the armature winding? EMF is generated ____________
column2: a) by rotating armature windings through a magnetic field
column3: b) by rotating magnetic field with respect to the armature windings
column4: c) by designing the magnetic circuit to have variable reluctance with rotor rotation
column7: Explanation: Any of the above mentioned methods will produce EMF in the armature windings.

column3: a) rotating speed of the armature coil
column4: b) rotating speed of the flux density wave
column5: c) relative velocity between the flux density wave and armature coil
column7: Explanation: fr is called the rotational or speed frequency, since its value depends upon the relative velocity between the flux density wave and the armature coil.

column7: Explanation: e = Emaxcos(_rt-π/2)_ = N_cos_rtIt reveals that the speed or generated EMF lags by 90° the flux that generates it, and is true when flux is time invariant and is sine distributed in space.

column1: 5. In a short pitched coil, the coil pitch factor kp, is given by ____________
column7: Explanation: The effect of short pitched coil is to reduce the generated EMF, and this reduction factor is cos_/2, and is referred to as coil pitch factor.

column7: Explanation: EMF induced = N__rkpsin_rt,Emax = N__rkp when sin_rt = 1RMS value, E = Emax/√2 = √2πfrkpN_

column1: 7. The effect of short pitched coil on the generated EMF is _____________
column7: Explanation: The effect of short pitched coil is to reduce the generated EMF and this reduction factor is cos_/2 and is referred to as coil pitch factor.

column1: 8. A winding is distributed in the slots along the air gap periphery
column2: (i) to add mechanical strength to the winding
column3: (ii) to reduce the amount of conductor material required
column4: (iii) to reduce the harmonics in generated EMF
column5: (iv) to reduce the size of the machine
column7: Explanation: In rotating electrical machines, the armature turns are usually distributed in slots rather than concentrated in single slot. This is essential from the view point of utilizing the armature  periphery completely, and add mechanical strength.

column1: 9. In an AC machine, the effect of distributing the turns in different slots, results in a further reduction of generated EMF by the factor kd. This factor is called ____________
column7: Explanation: E = √2πkpkdfrN_, kd is the distribution factor.

column1: 10. A polyphase induction motor of the slip ring or wound rotor type can be used ____________
column2: a) for high start-up torque applications
column7: Explanation: A polyphase induction motor can be used as a frequency converter (or changer) for changing the supply frequency f to other frequencies sf and (2-s)f at the slip ring terminals.

column1: 11. The equation for slip speed is ____________
column7: Explanation: The relative speed between rotor and rotating flux wave, i.e, (_-_r) is referred to as the slip speed in rad/secslip speed = (_-_r) rad/sec

column1: 12. If the rotor of an induction motor is made to revolve in a direction opposite to the rotating flux wave, then RMS value of EMF induced in one phase of rotor E is proportional to ____________
column7: Explanation: Relative velocity between rotor winding and rotating flux wave becomes(_+_r) = _+_(1-s) = _(2-s) andE = 2πf(2-s)Nphrkw_

column1: 13. In an alternator, frequency per revolution is equal to
column3: b) twice the number of poles
column7: Explanation: For a P-pole machine, in n rev/sec, P/2n cycles/second are generated and cycles per second is referred to as frequency f of the EMF wave. Here in this question n=1_ frequency per revolution = P/2_ number of pole pairs.

column1: 14. The EMF generated in an alternator depends upon
column7: Explanation: Eph = √2πfkwNph_, here _ = total flux per pole.

column1: 15. If the dimensions of all the parts of a synchronous generator and the number of field and armature turns are doubled, then the generated voltage will change by a factor of
column7: Explanation: E = √2πfrN_, _ = flux per pole = 4/pBplrdimensions are doubled _ l1 = 2l and r1 = 2r _ _1 = 4_No. of turns doubled _ N1 = 2N, fr changes only when the poles are changed _ fr1 = fr_ E1=√2πfr(2N)(4_) = 8EThe generated voltage will change by a factor of 8.

column1: 16. A 6 pole machine is rotating at a speed of 1200rpm. This speed in mechanical rad/sec and electrical radians per second is respectively
column7: Explanation: N = 1200rpm,P = 6 and f = PN/120 = 60 cycles per sec.1cycle = 360° electrical degrees = 2π electrical radiansf in electrical radians per sec = 60_2π electrical radians/sec = 120π elect radians/secspeed in mechanical radians/sec = 2/P(speed in electrical rad/sec) = 2/P(120π)=40π mechanical rad/sec.

column1: 17.The short pitch winding for an alternator gives
column2: (i) improved wave form of the generated EMF per phase
column3: (ii) reduced value of self inductance of the winding
column7: Explanation: The effect of short pitched coil is to reduce the generated EMF, and it improves waveform of EMF generated per phase, and as the windings are placed closed to each other, copper will be saved.

column1: 18. The DC machines are designed with flat topped flux density waves because
column2: a) average value of brush voltage is more for a flat topped B-wave
column3: b) average value of brush voltage is less for a flat topped B-wave
column4: c) losses for flat topped B-wave are less
column7: Explanation: For the same value of peak flux density Bp, it is easy to see that average value of brush voltage could be more for a flat topped B-wave than for a sinusoidal flux density wave.

column1: 1. For the given traction application using a dc series motor for a starting time ’t’ is applied. If this method is replaced by a series-parallel control, giving 50% time for each series and parallel. The saving in the starting energy of
column7: Explanation: Initially let the energy utilized was 100% for time t.Then for 50% duration for series, energy used is 50%. For parallel operation for the same circuit, the resistance gets halved assuming the same machine. So, for 50% of the parallel operation, 25% of energy is only utilized. Hence total saving is 25%.

column1: 2. If two series motors are identically coupled. One is running as motor while other as generator. For this combination,the iron losses and frictional losses are found identical for
column7: Explanation: For same iron and frictional losses, same frequency should be there. For that same speed must be run.

column1: 3. Hysteresis loss in a dc machine is _____ of rate of flow of air and _____ on frequency of _____
column7: Explanation: Hysteresis loss in a dc machine is independent of rate of flow of air and depends on frequency of magnetic reversal.

column1: 4. In dc machine iron losses cause
column4: c) rise in temperature of ventilating air
column7: Explanation: The iron losses cause heating of the core which causes reduction inefficiency and cooling air gets heated up.

column1: 5. For squirrel cage and slip ring induction motor, cooling methods is efficient in
column7: Explanation: As the squirrel cage induction motor has more ventilation and more space as compares to slip ring induction motor, there will be more efficient ways to cool down the squirrel cage motor.

column1: 6. If one of the phases of the supply breaks down, then the connected three phase induction motor
column2: a) continues to run as a single phase induction motor, provided load does does not increase beyond 57.7%
column3: b) stops operating after few seconds
column4: c) continues to run as single phase induction motor
column5: d) continues to run as two phase induction motor
column7: Explanation: When one of the phases breaks down then the other two phases will supply the rated current but the load should be reduced to 57.7%.

column1: 7. If one of the phases of RYB supply gets broken, then the temperature rise of the induction motor
column3: b) reduces as compared to the normal operating temperature
column4: c) reduces to temperature rise of corresponding single phase induction motor
column7: Explanation: The current flowing in the armature will remain same so to maintain the flux requirements of the machine.Hence the temperature rise will also remain same as the current remains same.

column1: 8. A three phase induction motor is connected to the infinite bus operating at the normal conditions. There occurs an unbalancing in the supply, leading to
column7: Explanation: The unbalancing in the supply phase will create an unbalanced distribution of the current in the phases, thereby unequal heating.

column1: 9. A peaky voltage supply is given to the 3 phase power transformer of the connection power system. These results into
column7: Explanation: The flux wave will be sinusoidal in nature as the emf is peaky in nature. Sine wave has least losses when compared to other wave forms.

column1: 11. The hydroelectric plants in the industry are best suited with
column7: Explanation: The closed circuit is so used to reuse the air in the system , so that to save water again in the cooling system.

column1: 1. A consideration of the power losses in electrical machines is essential for which of the following reasons?
column7: Explanation: A machine with lower efficiency has more losses, and therefore increased operating cost. Also, losses cause heating of the machine and therefore, its temperature rise. Similarly, voltage drop IR is associated with ohmic loss.

column1: 2. To determine the efficiency of the machine, direct load test is not advantageous because of which of the following reasons?
column2: a) Cost of providing large inputs
column3: b) Difficulty of dissipating the large outputs
column4: c) Both cost of providing large inputs and difficulty in dissipating the large outputs
column7: Explanation: Also, a small error in the measurement of either output or input causes the same amount of error in the computed efficiency.

column1: 3. Which of the following statements are correct regarding brush contact losses?
column2: a) In DC machine: proportional to armature current
column7: Explanation: There is brush contact loss at the contacts between the brushes and commutator (in DC machine) or between the brushes and slip rings (synchronous and induction machines). However, in practical, the brush contact loss is neglected for synchronous and induction machines.

column1: 4. In rotating electrical machines, when the armature rotates, there are continuous magnetic reversals and power required for their reversals is called _____________
column7: Explanation: Hysteresis loss is directly proportional to the number of magnetic reversals per second or the speed.

column1: 5. The usual lamination thickness selected to minimize the eddy current loss in rotor is _____________
column7: Explanation: If lamination thickness is made less than 0.4 mm, the reduction in eddy current losses is achieved, but at the cost of additional labor charges in assembling the rotor.

column1: 6. In an induction motor, which of the following is correct:
column2: a) Stator core loss < rotor core loss
column3: b) Stator core loss = rotor core loss
column4: c) Stator core loss > rotor core loss
column7: Explanation: The rotor core loss is almost negligible because of reduced frequency of the flux reversals (equal to slip frequency, sf) in the rotor, and Pe_f2 and Ph_f. ( Pe = eddy current losses,  Ph = hysteresis losses)

column1: 7. The pole shoes in DC and synchronous machines are laminated to reduce _____________
column7: Explanation: The pulsations in flux density wave arising from slot openings cause losses in the field iron, particularly in the pole faces. This loss occurring due to relative motion, between field poles and slotted armature, is referred to as pulsation loss.

column1: 8. What percentage of the rated output for DC machine and synchronous machine is taken as stray load losses respectively?
column7: Explanation: Stray load losses cannot be determined accurately. In DC machine, by convention, it is taken as 1% of the rated output for rating above 150 KW. For synchronous and induction machine, it is taken as 0.5% of their rated output.

column1: 9. Which of the given losses are directly proportional to square of speed?
column4: c) Both Windage and eddy current loss
column5: d) Hysteresis loss and brush loss
column7: Explanation: The windage loss includes the power required to circulate air through the machine and ventilating ducts, and is approximately proportional to the square of speed. Also, eddy current losses are proportional to square of speed.

column1: 10. Consider the following statements regarding efficiency of electrical machines:
column2: (i) efficiency should be calculated by measuring output and input
column3: (ii) efficiency is maximum when constant losses = variable losses
column4: (iii) electrical machines are designed to have maximum efficiency at full load
column5: (iv) electrical machines are designed to have maximum efficiency at near about full load
column7: Explanation: The machine efficiency rises with load. but at a particular load, efficiency is maximum and beyond this load, efficiency diminishes. Also, for both motors and generators, machine efficiency is maximum when variable loss = constant loss.

column1: 11. The electromechanical energy conversion devices used in power systems are never operated to deliver maximum power output, because at maximum power output, _____________
column3: b) Temperature of the power devices is much more than the specified allowable temperature rise
column4: c) Half of the power input appears as losses
column7: Explanation: In practice, devices are operated at a load somewhat less than rated load, at which the efficiency is maximum.

column1: 12. For the same rating machines, which of the following statement is correct regarding the efficiency (_)?
column2: a) _ of low speed machine > _ of high speed machine
column3: b) _ of low speed machine < _ of high speed machine
column4: c) _ of low speed machine = _ of high speed machine
column7: Explanation: The amount of conductor and iron materials required for a machine of given rating is inversely proportional to its speed. Also, more iron and conductor would entail more losses.

column1: 13. No load rotational losses in electrical machine consists of _____________
column3: b) Stator core, friction and windage losses
column4: c) Rotor core, friction and windage losses
column5: d) No load core, friction and windage losses
column7: Explanation: The sum of friction and windage loss under no load is called no load rotational losses.
